Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Remotely Operated Vehicles for Engaging and Retaining STEM Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a collaborative project involving Brevard College (Award DUE-1607952) and the Pisgah Astronomical Research Institute (PARI) (Award DUE-1607926). The investigators will redesign "gateway" STEM courses at a small liberal arts college around active-learning exercises and laboratories using technology, and will examine the effects on the engagement and retention of students in STEM. Specifically, over 400 students per year in introductory science classes at Brevard College will control remote rovers with sensors in the exploration of a 200-acre plot in the Pisgah National Forest in western North Carolina. Using an array of sensors, such as cameras, thermometers, soil moisture detectors, and a drill for geology studies, the remote-controlled robots will probe the forested environment. A submersible to study the water quality of stream-fed ponds is also part of the robot group. Students will experience the excitement of becoming researchers and guiding the rovers to explore. They will learn about flora and fauna and develop 21st-century technology skills needed in the STEM workforce. By using broadly applicable, state-of-the-art technology, the project will engage and inspire undergraduate students and faculty, while creating a set of institutional tools to share with peer institutions and informal science education centers.

The integration of engaging, experiential approaches using the rovers will create a rich learning environment in which students will see the connection between scientific theory and practice. Freshmen-level courses that will be affected include chemistry, biology, environmental science, geology, and physics. All students graduating from the college take at least one of the science courses plus one mathematics course. Instructors will incorporate the robotic manipulation, collection, and interpretation of data into these courses, especially the laboratory portions. By examining the rates of engagement and retention of students in STEM before and after the robotic technology has been implemented, the investigators will advance knowledge about the impact of innovative technology on undergraduate STEM education. The forest habitat data that will be gathered will also be valuable. A habitat map of a section of a national forest, which can be a longitudinal study, is important for environmental scientists and ecologists. Components of the project will be replicated and used at other colleges and science education centers, beginning with PARI, where educators plan to expand the project to summer and after-school programs, especially SciGirls and the North Carolina Girls STEM Collaborative.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ROVERS (Remotely Operated Vehicles Engaging and Retaining Students) Program has added numerous capabilities and opportunities to PARI (Pisgah Astronomical Research Institute).

Staff Capabilities

PARI staff now has four years of experience working with robotics.  Staff are now competent in robot design, microcontroller programming, use of sensors, 3D design and fabrication of parts, and systems for remote control via radio and WiFi.  These capabilities have already added to the outreach, educational programs, hands-on science kits, and visitor engagement that PARI offers.

Education Offerings & Outreach

A camp program has been designed and piloted and will continue to be offered.  In this camp, student teams build and program their own light seeking robot over the course of a week.  In a final competition, teams must see if their robot can reach the brightest part of a room faster than that of other teams.  The difficulty and tasks involved are scalable and the camp has been successfully completed by students ranging from 11 to 17 years old.

Additional camps had been scheduled with several Girl Scout troops but had to be postponed due to COVID-19.  PARI still intends to complete these camps at a later date when conditions allow.

An activity that is conducted at community outreach events and STEM festivals has been supported by the Rovers program, allowing young visitors to PARI?s booth to build and take home their own robot based on the ?bristle bot? design, a small vibrating robot that wiggles around like an insect.  For many participants this is the first robot they have ever built.  Over 500 kids have participated so far.

PARI has partnered with a local robotics team to provide robotics outreach at additional STEM events.

A program is in development to teach students to build web connected environmental sensors, allowing them to contribute to citizen science projects by deploying the sensors they build in their own communities.  It is intended that students participating in this program will come from a wide geographic area and will be able to view the contributions of their sensors to the project online.

Intern Support

PARI has supported interns and intern projects through the Rovers program, allowing them to gain experience in robotics and programming as well as environmental studies.  Interns have been able to explore many of the same topics that the PARI staff supporting the program have, with a focus on the design, creation, and maintenance rovers and their sensors.

In response to COVID-19, supported interns have created a robotics kit that can be mailed to students or sent to schools as well as instructions and videos to aid in the completion of the kit.  The purpose of this kit is to provide an experience in robotics simple enough to be completed with minimal guidance or need for equipment or facilities but set the stage for further engagement with robotics.

PARI interns benefiting from the resources and knowledge gained during the ROVERS program also designed and are fabricating a robotic carousel as part of a museum exhibit on spectroscopy.  This carousel can cycle bulbs through a fixture that are energized in turn and shown through a diffraction grating to demonstrate optical spectography without the need for an educator to switch out the bulbs.

Facility Capabilities

Tools and equipment to build and maintain robots are now available at PARI.  The existing rovers can be changed or enhanced to meet the needs of the schools and organizations with which we partner.  Students coming to our site can use the robotics labs and equipment to build their own robots and sensors.  The can print their own parts with 3D printers.

Outdoor areas have been set aside for the use of rovers.  These sites contain both natural areas in forested and grassy areas, as well as terrains that simulate what might be found on other planets.  PARI now maintains a server to manage the use and control of rovers and related resources, store the data collected by students, and share it with others.

Web Based Control

A control interface allowing students to use rovers remotely.  This interface contains user management, scheduling, data storage, search, and retrieval, and rover control and sensor monitoring.  It has been designed to work with low powered computers like chromebooks to maximize accessibility, and the data sent can be scaled to work with different internet speeds.

Future

PARI intends to continue using its knowledge and equipment to support rover use by schools and universities.  It will continue to integrate robotics and sensing into educational offerings, outreach, and camps.
